results.title: Isle of spice
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures and Van Beuren Corporation
results.brief_description: Short travelogue focusing on the island of Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). We are briefly introduced to various customs of the locals, and we see footage of activities such as fishing, the use of elephants to aid in heavy work, lacemaking and the coconut harvesting. Contains footage of 1930s Colombo.

results.title: Isle of bounty
results.creator_credit: Movietonenews, Australian National Film Board and Frank Coffey
results.brief_description: A study of the sub-tropical island where some of the crew of the famous Bounty mutiny settled and married Polynesian wives - Norfolk Island, one of the many Pacific Islands north-east of Australia.

results.title: Islands within islands within islands
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University, Andrew Crilly, Rodger Jones and Peter Firstbrook
results.brief_description: Studies the Hawaiian islands and the varied environments to be found there - eg deserts and frozen ash. Describes the formation of the islands and the ways in which plants may have migrated to newly formed volcanic islands. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC-TV, Open University, Andrew Crilly, Rodger Jones and Peter Firstbrook

results.title: Islands under the wind: Tahiti
results.creator_credit: Pan American World Airways, Henry Strauss Productions and Henry Strauss
results.brief_description: The leisurely life of the people of Tahiti and in particular the township of Papeete is depicted. Marketing, boating, fishing, dancing and going to church make up the lives of a people who work to live rather than live to work. The beautiful scenery of a typical tropical island forms a background to the dances and music of the islanders. Although, also showing the coconut industry, spear fishing and diving for pearl shell, the film primarily emphasises the scenic attractions and the easy life on the island. Narrated by Claude Dauphin.

results.title: Islands in the stream
results.creator_credit: Paramount Communications, Peter Bart, Max Palewsky and Franklin J. Schaffner
results.brief_description: Abridged version of Hemingway’s novel. An artist living alone on his island retreat is visited by his sons. Over the summer, he discovers their mutual need and respect. (This section, however, is not representative of the theme of the novel as a whole). Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Islands in the sky: the search for the Black Tree Kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Sky Visuals, ABC-TV (Australia) and Gary Steer
results.brief_description: Set in colourful Papua New Guinea, Tim Flannery, while ill, was being carried from the mountains when he noticed one of the stretcher bearers wore a black claw as pendant. This was the first piece in a biological detective story to locate a completely new species of mammal. Tim searched for 7 years until he found the Black Tree Kangaroo, or “Tenkile”. This creature had never been filmed before. It was one of the many animal survivors “marooned” on ecological islands in the sky, rainforest peaks isolated from lowland environments.

results.title: Islands in the sky
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Don Murray and Dietmar Fill
results.brief_description: Shows the summer wildflowers in Kosciusko National Park. Discusses adaptation of the plants to the hostile environment and includes an alpine herb field, ferns and bogs.

results.title: Island target
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Ralph Smart
results.brief_description: The story of one squadron of Australian airmen in action against the Japanese in the islands north of Australia. The work of the squadron included the covering of Allied landings and a hazardous attack on Japanese headquarteres on one particular island.

results.title: Island people
results.creator_credit: Realist Film Unit (Great Britain), John Taylor and Philip Leacock
results.brief_description:
How Six People Spend Saturday: “It is Saturday in Britain, the day divided between work and rest. In the morning six people, representative of various types, are seen at work in the industrial areas, on the farms and in the cities. They are a craftsman from the Midlands, a typist in a big Manchester office, a tug captain on the River Thames, a farmer from the Lowlands of Scotland, a woman doctor from Cardiff and a small boy who lives in a suburb.
At midday the people crowd out of offices, factories and schools, all going home to prepare for the half-holiday.
Saturday afternoon is set aside for enjoyment. Out they go to their games and amusements, to play football and hockey, rugby and running, to work in the garden, to walk in the woods. At the end of the afternoon they go out to various places of amusement, or they return home to read and play or to make clothes or model aeroplanes.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1940)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Realist Film Unit (Great Britain), John Taylor and Philip Leacock

results.title: Island of turtles
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Noel Monkman
results.brief_description: Turtles are found in the seas around the islands of the Great Barrier Reef, Queensland. Living most of its life in water the female turtle comes to land to lay her eggs in the sandy shores. After 9-10 weeks the eggs hatch out and the young turtles make their way to the sea. Also shows crested terns and other sea birds on the islands. Additional photography by C.P. Mountford.
